awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of an ultra performance liquid chromatography mass spectrometer (UPLC-MS) for multi-disciplinary research
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation (CRIF) Programs. Professor Paula Hudson from California State University Fullerton and colleagues Madeline Rasche, Sudarshan Kurwadkar, Nicholas Salzameda and Alexandra Orchard have acquired a benchtop quadrupole, liquid chromatograph tandem mass spectrometer (Q-LCMS/MS.) In general, mass spectrometry (MS) is one of the key analytical methods used to identify and characterize small quantities of chemical species embedded in complex samples. In a typical experiment, the components flow into a mass spectrometer where they are ionized into ions and the ions' masses are measured. This highly sensitive technique allows the structure of molecules in a complex mixtures to be studied. An instrument with a liquid chromatograph can separate mixtures of compounds before they reach the mass spectrometer.  The acquisition strengthens the research infrastructure at the University and regional area. The instrument broadens participation by involving diverse groups of students in research and research training using this modern analytical technique. It also provides training opportunities to many undergraduate students at this Hispanic-serving institution since they are the major workforce in research laboratories at CSUF. Additionally, research programs on the CSUF campus engage students from local community colleges through ten and twelve-week summer research experiences supported through the Regional Alliance in STEM Education (Project RAISE).

The mass spectrometer enhances research and education at all levels. This instrument especially impacts research on identification and quantification of atmospherically and environmentally relevant molecules.  It is used in rapidly characterizing ,with high accuracy, inhibitors of protein-protein interactions of enzymes related to human health and disease. The spectrometer is also used in designing enzyme assays to identify small molecule protease inhibitors and quantify small molecules used in the discovery and kinetic characterization of enzyme catalysts.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of this Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) award was to acquire an ultra performance liquid chromatography mass spectrometer (UPLC-MS) to enhance the research and teaching activities at California State University, Fullerton (CSUF), a diverse and highly ranked regional comprehensive university where undergraduate teaching, training and research intersect. The UPLC component of this instrument separates complicated mixtures and the mass spectrometer measures the mass of compounds to high accuracy. The ability to measure a broad range of samples rapidly and with high sensitivity enhances existing and enables new multidisciplinary undergraduate research. It further advances our mission of training a diverse, technically capable workforce by introducing our students in the classroom and lab to an instrument that has become an essential workhorse across a number of academic fields and industries. The specific objectives of the project were to: 1) identify and quantify molecules involved in atmospherically and environmentally relevant reactions; 2) obtain high accuracy mass spectral analysis of novel organic molecules for characterization; and 3) develop enzymatic assays for biologically and environmentally relevant molecules.

The objectives of the project were achieved and expanded. The instrument is currently used by the research labs of six different CSUF Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry faculty (PI Hudson, Co-PIs Rasche and Salzameda, and CSUF faculty Billingsley, de Lijser, and Pecic). Two of the faculty (Billingsley and Pecic) were hired after the acquisition of the instrument and have both become major users. Additionally, three separate collaborations with faculty at Marshall B. Ketchum University and the University of California, Irvine have been developed and have used the UPLC-MS system. It is through the research efforts of the faculty and collaborators that the above three objectives were met.

Several masters student thesis would have been impossible to complete without the acquisition of the UPLC-MS system. Six MS students projects (Edwin Aguilar, Tyler Hua, Marissa Kaak, Alex Ku, Anastasia Martinez and Stephanie Wilt) have included data acquired on the UPLC-MS system. Although, in some cases, the composition of the developed compounds could have been sent to outside facilities for compositional analysis, the ability to analyze samples 'in-house' saves both money and time. In particular, the UPLC-MS system was central to the theses of Hua (PI Hudson) and Aguilar (Co-PI Rasche) "GC-FID, LC-UV, and LC-MS instrument comparison: Analysis of biomass burning and photooxidation polycarboxylic acid products" and "Using liquid-chromatography mass spectrometry to explore the promiscuity of 4-(Β-D-ribofuranosyl) aminobenzene 5'-phosphate synthase, a potential target for anti-obesity treatment", respectively. Further, the research experiences of several undergraduate students in the research labs of the six faculty listed above have been enhanced from the acquisition of the UPLC-MS system. The work of the faculty, and the MS and undergraduate students in their research labs, has resulted in multiple conference presentations at undergraduate and national conferences and twelve different publications to date with thirty-six different undergraduate and four MS student co-authors.

The mission of our university is "to provide students with the best of current education practice and environment, through which students develop the habit of intellectual inquiry, prepare for challenging professions, and contribute productively to society". The acquisition of the UPLC-MS system has allowed CSUF faculty to train undergraduate students in modern techniques and provide high-level research training and professional development opportunities to our students.


Last Modified: 11/28/2021
Modified by: Paula Hudson
